properties.Title: Blowing Snow Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow combined with strong northwesterly winds will reduce visibilities to near zero Monday. ### Blowing snow advisories are issued when winds are expected to create blowing snow giving poor visibility to 800 metres or less for at least 3 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2021-03-01T18:03:02-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-03-01T02:04:02-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2359452692.2021

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds tonight and Monday. Winds have eased from their earlier peak this past evening. However, winds are forecast to strengthen again tomorrow morning, particularly along the shoreline of Whitefish Bay. Gusts up to 80 km/h can be expected from late morning into the early afternoon. Winds will diminish by evening. Power outages are possible. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2021-03-01T23:11:58-00:00

Area: Sault Ste. Marie - St. Joseph Island
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Winds gusting up to 90 kilometres per hour are expected along the shore Monday. ### Damage to buildings, such as to roof shingles and windows, may occur. Wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:

High winds may toss loose objects or cause tree branches to break. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snow, strong winds, and blowing snow expected. Snowfall: 15 to 25 cm, except 5 to 10 cm along parts of the coast. Maximum wind gusts: 80 km/h, except up to 120 km/h in areas prone to enhanced southeasterlies. Locations: western Newfoundland. Time span: this evening until Tuesday afternoon. Remarks: Local enhancement in southeasterly flow typically occurs in the vicinities of Cape St. George, Port au Port Bay, the outer Bay of Islands, Bonne Bay, Western Brook Pond and St. Pauls Bay. ### Visibility will be suddenly reduced to near zero at times in heavy snow and blowing snow. Winter storm warnings are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2021-03-02T00:40:56-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-03-01T08:41:56-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1373902495.2021
Area: Corner Brook and vicinity, Gros Morne, Bay St. George, Parson's Pond - Hawke's Bay
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Wind chill values of approximately minus 40 are expected beginning Monday and continuing Tuesday. An Arctic air mass combined with moderate winds will produce extreme cold conditions. ### Watch for cold related symptoms: shortness of breath, chest pain, muscle pain and weakness, numbness and colour change in fingers and toes. Extreme cold warnings are issued when very cold temperatures or wind chill creates an elevated risk to health such as frost bite and hypothermia. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2021-03-01T18:05:25-00:00

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snowfall possible mid-week. Locations: the Labrador Coast from Nain to Black Tickle. Time span: Wednesday afternoon into Thursday morning. Remarks: A storm may affect the Labrador Coast mid-week. While it is too soon to provide specific details, the potential exists for strong winds accompanied by significant amounts of snow. Additional information will be provided as the details become more certain. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Title: Winter Storm Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snowfall Tuesday Snowfall amounts may possibly exceed 25 centimetres beginning early Tuesday morning. Strong easterly winds combined with snow are expected to reduce visibilities to zero in the blowing snow. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Winter storm watches are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.

properties.Title: Weather Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Winter Weather Travel Advisory in effect for tonight. Snowfall with total amounts of 10 to 15 cm is expected. Snow, at times heavy, will affect parts of northeastern Ontario tonight. Additionally, strong northwest winds gusting up to 70 km/h will develop late this evening creating localized areas of blowing snow. Dangerous winter driving conditions due to heavy snow and blowing snow are expected. Be prepared to adjust your driving with the changing road conditions. Conditions are expected to improve by Monday morning. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

Locations: Codroy Valley eastward to the Ramea area. Time span: this evening until Tuesday morning. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility. properties.Title: Snow Squall Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Local snow squalls possible tonight into Monday afternoon. Locally heavy snowfall amounts of 4 to 8 cm will be possible by the time the snow squalls weaken late Monday afternoon. The heavy snow, combining with strong northwesterly winds gusting up to 80 km/h, may result in near zero visibilities in heavy snow and blowing snow at times. Motorists should prepare for adverse winter driving conditions and adjust their travel plans accordingly. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Snow squall watches are issued when conditions are favourable for brief but intense bursts of heavy snow producing near zero visibilities. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

Winter storm warnings are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.

properties.Title: Wreckhouse Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Very strong wind gusts are expected or occurring Maximum gusts: southeasterly up to 140 km/h in the Wreckhouse area. Time span: this evening until Tuesday morning. Remarks: Southeasterly winds gusting to 100 km/h will develop this evening then increase to 140 km/h overnight. Winds will ease upon shifting to strong southwesterly Tuesday morning. ### Drivers may lose control of their vehicles; tall vehicles are at risk of being overturned. Wreckhouse wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Summary:

Remarks: Strong west to northwest winds gusting to 90 km/h will develop near noon on Tuesday and persist through to overnight Tuesday. These strong winds may cause blowing snow over exposed areas giving reduced visibilities. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.

properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A period of very cold wind chills is expected. Wind chill values between minus 45 and minus 50 are expected overnight tonight and continue until late Monday morning. ### Extreme cold warnings are issued when very cold temperatures or wind chill creates an elevated risk to health such as frost bite and hypothermia. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds that may cause damage are expected or occurring. Maximum wind gusts: 90 km/h. Locations: northeastern New Brunswick. Time span: Tuesday and Tuesday night. Remarks: Strong west to northwest winds gusting to 90 km/h along parts of the coast will develop early Tuesday morning and persist through Tuesday night. Winds are expected to drop below warning criteria by Wednesday morning. These strong winds may cause blowing snow over exposed areas giving reduced visibilities. ### High winds may toss loose objects or cause tree branches to break. Wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NBStorm.

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds that may cause damage are expected or occurring. Maximum gusts: southeasterly 80 km/h, except 100 over exposed areas. Locations: the Bonavista and northern Avalon Peninsulas. Time span: Tuesday morning until Tuesday evening. ### Damage to buildings, such as to roof shingles and windows, may occur. Loose objects may be tossed by the wind and cause injury or damage. Wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Title: Weather Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Winter Weather Travel Advisory in effect for tonight. Snowfall with total amounts of 10 to 15 cm is expected. Snow, at times heavy, will affect parts of northeastern Ontario tonight. Additionally, strong northwest winds gusting up to 70 km/h will develop late this evening creating localized areas of blowing snow. Dangerous winter driving conditions due to heavy snow and blowing snow are expected. Be prepared to adjust your driving with the changing road conditions. Conditions are expected to improve by Monday morning. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 15 to 25 cm is expected. Time span: late this afternoon until overnight tonight. Locations: Magdalen Islands. Remarks: Snow, heavy at times, will develop over the islands beginning late this afternoon and will likely change over to a few rain showers overnight tonight. Strong westerly winds will develop Tuesday behind the storm. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.

properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A period of very cold wind chills is expected. Light north winds combined with temperatures in the mid minus forties will result in wind chill values of -55 or lower on Monday morning. Wind chill values will moderate slightly Monday afternoon however extreme wind chill values are expected to return to the area Monday night into Tuesday morning. ### Watch for cold related symptoms: shortness of breath, chest pain, muscle pain and weakness, numbness and colour change in fingers and toes. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 15 to 25 cm is expected. Time span: today and tonight. Locations: central and northern New Brunswick Remarks: Snow, heavy at times, will spread eastward across central and northern New Brunswick this morning. Temperatures will rise above zero in some places this afternoon which will cause partial melting of the snow as it falls, which could make it heavy to move. Snow will taper to flurries by Tuesday morning then strong northwesterlies will develop bringing a very cold airmass. Some blowing snow is possible on Tuesday especially over exposed areas. ### Rapidly accumulating snow will make travel difficult. Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NBStorm.
